awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: New Directions in Public-Key and Identity-Based Encryption
awd_abstract_narration:
Developments in public-key encryption (PKE) and identity-based encryption (IBE) have revolutionized the field of cryptography and secure communication in general. PKE allowed remote parties to establish secure channels in front of eavesdropping adversaries, and led to public-key directories storing parties' public-keys. The stronger primitive of IBE eliminated the need for a large public-key directory, though this comes at the cost of trusting a central private-key generation authority. Decades after introduction of PKE and IBE, our understanding of the complexity of these tasks, in terms of what they can offer and the intractability assumptions needed for building them, is still very limited. At a high level, the goal of the project is to make progress exactly on these fronts. The project's novelties include a study of new cryptographic tools that give best of both IBE and PKE as well as developing new techniques for basing IBE and PKE on optimal intractability assumptions. The project impact is through new ways to secure communication. In addition, the collaboration between the investigators will help enhance the education of the graduate students at both institutes.

More specifically, the goals of this project are pursued in two directions: (1) enhancements from minimal assumptions and (2) identifying barriers and proving lower bounds. The first direction of the project focuses on obtaining enhanced security for IBE and PKE from minimal assumptions. The efforts above on designing constructions from minimal assumptions would not be complete without having a formal understanding about when we have achieved optimal results. The second principal component of this project focuses on identifying those minimal assumptions. Specifically, the project's goal is to prove black-box and non-black-box barriers and (efficiency) lower bounds, complementing the results proved in the first direction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to open up new directions in public-key and identity-based encryption. More specifically, we aimed for understanding minimal assumptions and barriers as well as proving lower bounds. See the abstract (above) for more details.

Students and mentoring: With the help of this grant, and during the course of four years of this grant, the PI supported five graduate students.

Publications: With the valuable help of this grant, the PI published 11 papers in top conferences of: ICALP ‘20, ITCS ‘21, IEEE S&P (Oakland) ‘21, TCC ‘21, Crypto ‘22, TCC ‘22, Eurocrypt ‘23 (2 papers), ITC ‘23, TCC ‘23, and Asiacrypt ‘23.

Now, we highlight some of the key research outcomes supported by this grant.

New directions in proving barriers: in our ITCS ‘21 paper, we initiated a new direction in proving black-box lower bounds by introducing the notion of “black-box uselessness”. This means that when we aim to construct primitive Q, another primitive P might be completely useless, even along with other primitives, so long as it is used as black-box. We also proved partial results about how useful OWFs are key agreements. 

Complexity of key agreement: In our Eurocrypt ‘23 paper, we initiated a study of the (tight) fine-grained security of non-interactive key exchange in idealized models. We extended Merkle’s classical result to the multiparty setting and provided initial results (some with a matching lower bound) in stronger generic models such as the GGM. In our Crypto ‘22 paper, we initiated a formal study of whether the classic IR89 lower bound (about getting key agreements from OWFs) extends to the local quantum computation setting (with classical communications). We showed that under believable conjectures about low degree polynomials, this barrier can be extended to the quantum setting (for the case of perfect completeness). Resolving the full general case has remained open.

Complexity of sequential (public key) primitives: In our ICALP ‘20 paper, we showed that natural forms of “verifiable delay functions’ cannot be built from random oracles. Currently, verifiable delay functions rely on much stronger assumptions than those obtained from ideal hash functions. In our Asiacrypt ‘23 paper we looked at another sequential primitive: time-lock puzzles, and showed that local quantum reductions cannot enable them from random oracles if the communication remains classical.

Complexity of registration based encryption (RBE): One major focus of this project was to understand the limitations of RBE, as a new primitive initiated by the PI and colleagues with the hope of eliminating key escrow from identity-based encryption. We made significant progress in this regard. In particular, we published three papers about RBE. In our TCC ‘22 paper, we proved that natural forms of RBE suffer from an `almost logarithmic’ number of decryption updates being necessary. The bound was not tight as there was a loglog(n) factor between the lower bound and known positive results. In our ITC ‘23 paper, we closed this gap by improving the constructions of RBE to match the lower bound. Finally, in our TCC ‘23 paper, we proved the first nontrivial lower bound on the assumption complexity of RBE, showing that they cannot be built from trapdoor permutations.

In summary, the above outcomes build the foundation for future studies about registration based encryption and its various connections to public key cryptography and beyond.
